title: RS21364
content: Supervised release replaced parole in the federal criminal justice system in 1984. It applies to federal crimes committed after November 1, 1987, and involves a period of supervision post-release. The terms and conditions are determined by sentencing courts and failure to comply can result in reincarceration. The sentencing courts have broad discretion in imposing conditions for supervised release, within the confines of mandatory and discretionary conditions. The Sentencing Guidelines recommend supervised release in most felony cases, starting upon actual release. There is a split among circuits on when the term of supervised release begins for a defendant. The term of supervised release for a defendant begins when released from federal custody, even if multiple terms are served concurrently. Section 3583(b) sets the duration of supervised release based on the felony conviction, ranging from one to five years. The term of supervised release for a defendant is determined by the felony conviction, with exceptions for certain offenses like drug, terrorism, and sex crimes which can have supervised release terms up to life. Mandatory minimum terms apply based on the offense, volume, and criminal record, with a minimum of five years for kidnaping a child and certain sex offenses. Terrorism offenses require a term of supervised release as well. The courts must impose a term of supervised release for certain offenses listed in 18 U.S.C. 2332b(g)(5)(B), regardless of terrorist intent. The court can terminate or extend supervised release based on the defendant's conduct and sentencing factors. Conditions for supervised release are determined during the initial sentencing based on the offense and defendant's history. When determining conditions for supervised release, courts consider federal statutory requirements and Sentencing Guidelines. There are mandatory and discretionary conditions, with mandatory conditions including refraining from criminal activity, cooperating with DNA collection, and submitting to drug tests. All prisoners must agree to a payment schedule for unpaid fines before release, but it is not specified if this agreement will be enforced during supervised release. The Sentencing Guidelines mandate fines and restitution as conditions of supervised release. Additional conditions apply to domestic violence and sex offenses, such as attending rehabilitation programs and registering with authorities. Courts have discretion to impose additional conditions, like deportation for aliens. The court can impose various conditions on supervised release, including deportation for aliens and warrantless searches for sex offenders. These conditions must be related to sentencing goals and not overly restrictive. Sentencing Guidelines provide guidance on discretionary conditions, suggesting some and proposing additional considerations. The Sentencing Guidelines outline three groups of discretionary conditions for supervised release: "standard" conditions, "special" conditions for specific cases, and "additional" conditions like community confinement and curfews. These conditions ensure regular contact with probation officers, including reporting, visits, and following instructions. The standard conditions for supervised release include following the probation officer's instructions, notifying of address or employment changes, staying in the district unless approved, reporting arrests or questioning by law enforcement, avoiding criminal associations and drug use, staying employed, and honoring legal obligations such as supporting family and paying assessments. The discretionary conditions for supervised release include special conditions tailored to the individual case, such as banning possession of weapons for certain offenses or individuals with prior felony convictions. These conditions address specific factors like the nature of the offense and the defendant's character. Special conditions for supervised release can include sex-offender treatment, computer use restrictions, and warrantless searches for sex or child pornography offenses. Other conditions may involve drug or mental health treatment programs, deportation for eligible aliens, and financial restrictions like prohibiting new credit charges without approval. Special conditions for supervised release can include demands for financial information, restrictions on mobility and work activities like community confinement and curfews. The federal Sentencing Guidelines advise caution in imposing excessive restrictions on defendants' freedom of movement. The court may impose a discretionary condition of supervised release for up to six months, with the possibility of a longer period for specific rehabilitative programs. Community service conditions are limited to 400 hours. The condition must be reasonably related to the offense, defendant, public safety, and other sentencing factors. The court may impose discretionary conditions of supervised release for up to six months, with the possibility of a longer period for specific rehabilitative programs. Conditions must be reasonably related to the defendant's history, protection of the public, and rehabilitation. The courts have the authority to order conditions that involve no greater deprivation of liberty than is reasonably necessary. The court may impose discretionary conditions of supervised release for up to six months, with the possibility of a longer period for specific rehabilitative programs. Conditions must be reasonably related to the defendant's history, protection of the public, and rehabilitation. A considerable deprivation of liberty will be considered justified when clearly related to a serious crime and criminal history, while a serious deprivation of liberty will not be justified if the connection is tenuous. Some courts view the standard as a "narrow tailoring requirement" to choose the least restrictive alternative. The third discretionary condition requirement, consistent with Guidelines' Policy Statements, mandates that conditions not directly conflict. The court retains broad discretion in modifying supervised release conditions, including early termination, modification, or revocation of the term. Conditions must be reasonably related to certain factors and not directly conflict with policy statements. Courts evaluate challenges to supervised release conditions under specific statutes, ensuring they align with the defendant's history, public protection, and rehabilitation. The court has discretion to modify supervised release conditions, including early termination or revocation. Conditions must align with specific factors and not conflict with policy statements. Challenges to conditions are evaluated based on statutes to ensure they consider the defendant's history, public protection, and rehabilitation. Revocation of supervised release is required for certain violations like unlawful drug possession or refusal to comply with drug testing. The Sentencing Guidelines mandate revocation of supervised release for certain violations, such as drug-related offenses or repeated positive drug tests. Courts have the authority to revoke supervised release for other breaches of conditions. Defendants facing revocation have some, but not all, rights of a criminal trial, including prompt appearance before a magistrate. Revocation jurisdiction expires when the supervised release term ends, unless the process began before expiration or the defendant is imprisoned for 30 days or more due to a criminal conviction. The defendant facing revocation of supervised release is entitled to a probable cause preliminary hearing with appointed counsel if needed. At the revocation hearing, the defendant can present evidence, make a statement, and confront witnesses, but is not entitled to a jury or proof beyond a reasonable doubt. Upon revocation of supervised release, a defendant may face imprisonment for up to five years, followed by a new term of supervised release. Appellate courts will generally uphold the sentence imposed unless it is deemed unreasonable. The Constitution limits the conditions that can be imposed, and any condition violating a defendant's constitutional rights will be invalidated. The Constitution limits the conditions that can be imposed on supervised release, ensuring they do not violate a defendant's constitutional rights. The issue often arises in determining the extent of discretion given to probation officers in crafting conditions for defendants. The line between permissible and impermissible delegation is not always clear, especially when it involves a defendant's significant liberty interest. The court may impose conditions on supervised release, with some discretion delegated to probation officers. First Amendment challenges arise regarding sex offender conditions, particularly in terms of overbreadth and freedom of association. Overbreadth occurs when a condition restricts constitutionally protected speech. The right to intimate relationships is also recognized. Defendants often argue that conditions are overbroad or infringe on their rights. The Fourth Amendment guarantees protection against unreasonable searches and seizures, but after a criminal conviction, the Supreme Court uses a "general balancing" test to assess the intrusion on privacy versus the promotion of legitimate interests for individuals on supervised release. This balancing test ensures that government actions are necessary and do not unnecessarily deprive individuals of their liberty. Individuals on supervised release have reduced privacy expectations under the Fourth Amendment. Section 3583(d) allows warrantless searches for sex offenders. The Fifth Amendment requires due process for revocation hearings. Due process rights for individuals on supervised release include the right to a prompt hearing, adequate notice, representation, the opportunity to make a statement, and confront adverse witnesses. The extent to which a condition of supervised release may restrict access to one's children is also influenced by due process. Challenges to the constitutionality of vague conditions of supervised release are common, as they must provide clear notice of prohibited conduct to individuals of reasonable intelligence. The Sixth Amendment rights do not apply to supervised release revocation hearings, including the right to a speedy trial and a jury trial. The Eighth Amendment prohibits cruel and unusual punishment. The Eighth Amendment prohibits cruel and unusual punishment, including sentences of supervised release. Challenges to such sentences are rare and even more rarely successful.
